Today's tip is by #BrainFood Psychologist Elaine Slater.

 'If you struggle with emotional eating it is really important that you manage your stress levels by reaching out to a support network of friends, family, colleagues or a counsellor. Talking about your problems reduces the chances of binging, which only produces an initial short-term high followed by sugar withdrawal and then cravings. These highs and lows can have a detrimental effect on your mood, brain function and psychological health".

'Coaching helps you to identify or rediscover what you really want in life and encourages you to make the commitment to take ongoing daily action to make your dreams a reality' says life coach, Suzy Greaves.

Think coaching could help you? Then enter our competition to win a one on one session with Suzy, a session with psychotherapist Lucy Beresford, plus two Psychologies subscriptions and a year's supply of inspiring books!

Pick up a copy of the February issue to enter! Timeline Photos.

Make 2013 your best year yet....

COMPETITION! 

To help one reader achieve their long-desired dreams and ambitions, we’re giving away a brilliant package to help them stay motivated over the next 12 months.

The inspiring prize consists of: 
A one-to-one session with psychotherapist Lucy Beresford
A one-to-one appointment with life coach Suzy Greaves
Two Psychologies subscriptions to keep you motivated throughout 2013
A year’s supply of inspiring self-development books, memoirs and novels, one for each month of 2013.

Details to enter this life changing competition can be found in our feature-packed February issue on sale 2nd Jan 2013! Timeline Photos.

One day left of 2012! 

Which means only two days until our Feb issue goes on sale on 2nd Jan! But in the mean time, keep logged onto the website for some fantastic web-features on your 2013 goals, fresh starts and motivation, New Year tests and the next installment of our detox diary.... Timeline Photos.

Strangely useful tip of the day: Including vegetables in a meal can make people think you are not only a better cook, but also better person. 

Recent research found that adding vegetables to a meal led to better evaluations of the dinner, and also more positive descriptions of the chef! Another reason to eat your 5 a day! Timeline Photos.

Have you tried the 'Yes, and' concept? A technique used by comedians (agree and add a comment), it can help keep a conversation flowing, and even promote creativity. Try it today in a chat with your boss or whilst networking and see where it takes you. Timeline Photos.

In the December issue Dossier: Find meaning in your life

Do you ever wake up in the morning wondering is there more to life than this? Do you yearn for greater fulfilment? You may have ticked all the boxes, but still sense there is something missing.  Finding greater meaning if your life means aligning with your true sense of purpose and tapping into what matters most to you.

This months dossier will give advice on how to reconnect with your motivations, deal positively with life's disappointments and celebrate your life. Timeline Photos.

This month, Suzy Greaves is focusing on how we can all be more positive in our everyday lives.

You'll be glad to hear, today of all days, that the first key to happiness, is GIVING! 1st Key to Happiness: Giving. This year, why not create your own Happiness Club in your home? You’ll be on your way to more happiness and be able to spread some, too. This time, with help from our partners Action for Happiness, our focus is on the first key to happiness, giving. This time, with help from our partners Action for Happiness, our focus is on the first key to happiness, giving. Psychologies editor Suzy Greaves finds out more….

Get happy from the outside in... Get happy from the outside in. How many times have you heard about getting happy from the inside out? The promise of this kind of happiness is much deeper, sweeter, stable and authentic than external rewards. However, there is a way to get this deep sense of wellbeing from the outside in….

Create a happier world... Create a happier world. Psychologies' editor was speaking on the same stage as the Dalai Lama last week at Action for Happiness' launch of their new course Exploring What Matters. Suzy Greaves looks into the new Initiative for happiness and invites you to take your own action for happiness.

How to be more patient and tolerant... How to be more patient and tolerant. After going to see HH Dalai Lama in London yesterday on International Peace Day, I'm reminded how important it is for us all to show patience and tolerance to others, as a way of also promoting compassion, care and happiness.
Feeling the pinch? How to be happy on a budget... How to be happy on a budget. Catherine Jones has the lowdown.

How to create a happier and more caring world with the Dalai Lama... Happy with His Holiness. It's World Peace Day on Monday 21st September and I am honoured to be talking on the same stage as the Dalai Lama, the patron for Action for Happiness. Why not start your Happiness Club on World Peace Day?
Read your way to happiness - books can make you happy... Reading books can make you happy. Health writer Martha Roberts on how you can read your way to happiness.

This month, Suzy Greaves, Psychologies’ editor, is focusing on bouncing back from adversity.

Joy vs. Happiness: what's the difference? Joy vs Happiness. Joy and happiness are wonderful feelings to experience, but are very different. Joy is more consistent and is cultivated internally. It comes when you make peace with who you are, why you are and how you are, whereas happiness tends to be externally triggered and is based on other people, things, pl….

The power of equine therapy. The power of equine therapy. Amy Fleming was a stressed city-dweller with little time for reflection. But equine therapy, which harnesses the sensitivity of horses to reflect our emotions, changed her thinking and behaviour...

Test: How brave are you? Test: How brave are you? How do you react when faced with danger, or painful or difficult times? Are you impulsive, reflective, or do you hesitate? Take this test by psychotherapist Christophe André to find out.

Lots of things might be holding you back: internal conflict, giving things up when you didn’t want to, unsatisfactory compromises. If you can identify the signs of inner discord you can start to understand their causes and find a better way of being. By Flavia Mazelin Salvi.

If you find yourself putting obstacles in the way of your goals, use this quick test from Kim Morgan to find out what deep-seated beliefs are getting in the way of you achieving what you want...
Test: How do you communicate? Test: How do you communicate? How you talk to each other reveals a lot about your relationship. Take this quiz by psychologist Dr Rebecca McGuire-Snieckus.
How to develop your emotional resilience... How to develop your emotional resilience... Anita Chaudhuri tells us about developing resilience in your daily life.

Take our test: what kind of self-saboteur are you? Test: What kind of self-saboteur are you? At times the only thing standing between you and success is you. Take this test, by Dr Rebecca McGuire-Snieckus, psychologist at The Mind Gym, to discover your negative patterns and find strategies to help you break the cycle.

Test: Do you know how to be happy? Test: Do you know how to be happy? How important is being happy? Do you do everything in your power to seek out pleasure? Take this test by psychiatrist and psychotherapist Christophe André to find out how much of a hedonist you are...

Test: Are you too hard on yourself? Test: Are you too hard on yourself? Some people always judge themselves harshly, while others are more tolerant of their own faults. Do you punish yourself? Take our quick test by Christophe André and find out how forgiving you are about your own perceived and real shortcomings or errors.
Test: How do you recharge your batteries? Test: How do you recharge your batteries? What’s your best method for boosting energy levels? Take this test to find out.

Test: What’s holding you back from making a new start? Test: What’s holding you back from making a new start? Failure, betrayal, loss or even unexpected blessings: some things in life stop us in our tracks, making it difficult to move on. Take our test to discover what’s holding you back...

Test: How do you approach the future? Test: How do you approach the future? What's your view of the future, and what can you do about it? Take this quiz by psychologist Dr Rebecca McGuire-Snieckus to find out.

Looking to 2017? Take our test - are you ready to make your comeback? Test: Are you ready to make your comeback? Would you like to showcase your photographic talents in the magazine and online? 

Submit your photograph on this month's theme of 'LUCK' and we’ll print the winning photograph in the next issue of Psychologies magazine and on www.psychologies.co.uk the following month.

Please send your photograph attached in an email to pictures@psychologies.co.uk by midnight on 31 March.

Please include the email subject as ‘Photo Competition’ and the following information :

Your name
Your address
Your contact telephone number
A caption of up to 50 words about your photograph
Date and location of photograph
Images must be attached as a jpeg at 300dpi up to 5MB.
The winning image, along with next month’s competition theme will be announced in the April issue. Timeline Photos.

Film review: Midnight Special
This film takes you on a journey. You aren’t quite sure where you are going at first, but by the time the credits roll you’ll be staring at the screen with wonder.
Eight year-old Alton (Jaeden Lieberher) is on the run with his father (Michael Shannon) from a religious cult in Texas. As we get to know the pair, his father constantly tense and Alton seeming much wiser than the usual eight-year-old, we come to realise that there is more to this little boy than first meets the eye.
When it transpires that the FBI are after him as well as the cult leader, and his strange powers become apparent, just like his family, you’ll be rooting for him to find where he belongs in the world.
With an amazing score, an incredible cast including Kirstin Dunst and Adam Driver, and themes around family and what we sacrifice for the ones we love and the things we believe in, this is a realistic sci-fi movie guaranteed to keep you gripped until the end. Midnight Special.

Grace of Monaco might have flopped at Cannes, but it tells a fascinating story for women who have faced the decision of giving up their career for a family... Film review: Grace of Monaco. Grace Of Monaco, directed by Olivier Dahan, is in cinemas now.

Psychologies Book Review:

'The Son' by Philipp Meyer (Simon & Schuster, £7.99)
This epic novel takes place over two centuries in Texas and follows the dynastic McCullough family, who made their fortune in oil. From patriarch Eli’s years spent as a captured Indian, to his great-granddaughter Jeannie running the family business in the present day, Meyer’s scope and skill is masterful. Timeline Photos.

Psychologies Book Review

'The Ocean At The End Of The Lane' by Neil Gaiman (Headline, £7.99)
When a man commits suicide in a car outside a family’s B&B in rural Sussex, dark forces are unleashed that will haunt the young protagonist for the rest of his life. An almost adult fairytale steeped in magic, childhood and lost innocence, it will capture your imagination and your heart. Timeline Photos.

Psychologies Book Review:

'Burial Rites' by Hannah Kent (Picador, £7.99)
This exquisite novel is based on the true case of Agnes Magnusdottir, the last woman to be executed in Iceland. Sentenced to death in 1829 for murdering her lover, Agnes spends what are to be her final months with a family who took her in. Evocative and emotional, this is a stunning piece of historical fiction. Timeline Photos.

New Psychologies Book Review: 

'Apple Tree Yard' by Louise Doughty (Faber & Faber, £7.99)

Yvonne Carmichael is a happily married scientist who, after giving evidence at a House of Commons Select Committee, finds herself caught up in a passionate encounter with a complete stranger. But that spontaneous decision ends in tragedy, and she ends up on trial for murder. A gripping and intelligent thriller. Timeline Photos.

It's World Book Day, so here's our book of the month review:

'We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves' by Karen Joy Fowler (Profile, £12.99)

Rosemary Cooke is an only child. But that wasn’t always the case – she had an older brother, Lowell, and an older sister, Fern. But Fern disappeared and Lowell ran away, leaving Rosemary to be brought up alone by her scientist parents. What starts off as a seemingly traditional narrative about a slightly unusual family suddenly grabs you by the throat and throws you off a cliff, as you desperately flip back through the pages to absorb a truly shocking twist. Without giving the plot away (because it’s a corker), <We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves> is a moving portrait of an American family, and raises questions and feelings you never knew you had – about humanity, psychology and love in all its forms. It is a masterful novel, painful and memorable, and, like all the best novels, it will stay with you long afterwards. By Stacey Bartlett

#books #review #worldbookday. Timeline Photos.

This time we're watching 'The Invisible Woman' ... find out about the film here and get involved! Psychologies Film Club: ‘The Invisible Woman’. Last month Psychologies launched its first ever Film Club with ‘The Railway Man’. The Psychologies Film Club gives you the opportunity to interact with your tribe and discuss films - themes, storylines and characters with other Psychologies followers. This month, we're watching ‘The Invisible Woman’ starring Felicity Jones and Ralph Fiennes.

**Psychologies FILM CLUB: The Invisible Woman**

Out in UK cinemas 7 February

Synopsis:
Storming across a beautifully blustery Margate beach, we find Nelly (Felicity Jones), a haunted woman who cuts a very different figure to the same young woman who, years earlier at only 18, first encounters the talented, legendary, and older, Charles Dickens (Ralph Fiennes).
Trapped in a lifeless marriage and the isolation of his fame, Dickens tenderly pursues the young actress who, despite disapproving of relations outside of wedlock, finds herself succumbing to her literary idol’s advances. 
A story of guilt, shame and secrecy, their relationship has its own trials before Nelly is forced to live an invisible life with Dickens until his death separates them. But while he lives on through the words of his fans and in the books on her shelves, will she ever be able to forget him? 

Psychologies Film Club questions to discuss:

•	Do you think Charles Dickens took advantage of Nelly's position, or did he truly love her?

•	In later life, Nelly is still consumed by her past relationship. What past events still haunt you now?

•	Nelly lead an invisible life for the sake of her relationship. Would you do the same in the name of love?

What are your thoughts?

Do you feel like another relative is taking your place in your family? Read Lucy Beresford’s advice for our reader with this dilemma: My sister-in-law is taking my place « Psychologies. I have always got on well with my older brother’s wife, but recently my mum has been ill and, because I live a couple of hours away, they have been spending a lot of time together. All I hear from my mum is how wonderful she is. I’m grateful Mum isn’t on her own, but I feel my sister-in-law is tryin...

My parents try to involve me « Psychologies. My parents have always had a turbulent relationship and have split up more than once. The last time it happened, three years ago, they both swore that they wouldn’t get back together and my dad moved out. Now they’ve mentioned that they’d like to give it another go. I really don’t want to get involv...

Are you running away from life or running towards it?

This month, our expert advice columnist, Lucy Beresford, answers a readers dilemma: 

'After a career change three years ago, I am again reevaluating my life and contemplating another change in career and move to Australia. I worry I am running from something and that I'll never find a suitable career.'

Lucy replies: 'It sounds like you want and deserve some relaxation and a chance to explore other sides of you. But often our gut feeling about a situation can be revealing. Maybe what you are running from is other peoples expectations of you, or the idea of 'settling down'. Or maybe you are using the implied criticism of running away as an obstacle to pastures new? Ask yourself truthfully about your career and what you mean by 'suitable'. 

Knowing ourselves is a lifelong process, so I'd say the more experiences we can have to find out who we are, the better.'

For more Dilemmas, pick up the February issue or see our online archive by searching 'Dilemmas' in our homepage search engine at www.psychologies.co.uk. Psychologies.
